member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.CheckCRC32
member.summary: Calculates a checksum value for the entry and compares it to the checksum that was stored when the entry was created.
member.returns: True if the checksum values match, false otherwise.
member.remarks: This method is used to check the integrity of the entries in the zip file. If the calculated checksum does not match the stored checksum, then either the zip file is corrupted or the program used to create the zip file is incompatible with C1Zip.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.CheckPassword
member.summary: Checks whether this can be read with the currently set password.
member.returns: True if the entry can be read with the current password, or if the entry is not encrypted.
member.remarks: This method is more efficient than using a try/catch block and trying to open the entry to determine whether the current password is valid for the entry.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.OpenReader
member.summary: Returns a that can be used to read the content of the entry without extracting it to a disk file.
member.returns: A that can be used to read the data in the entry.
member.remarks: The returned is a , which decompresses the data as it is read from the entry.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.FileName
member.summary: Gets the entry name. This is usually a file name, optionally including a path.

member.summary: Gets the original (uncompressed) size of the entry, in bytes.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.SizeCompressed
member.summary: Gets the compressed size of the entry, in bytes.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.CRC32
member.summary: Gets the checksum calculated when the entry was compressed.
member.remarks: This value can be used to check the integrity of the entry when it is decompressed.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntry.Date
member.summary: Gets the date and time when the file used to create the entry was last modified.
member.remarks: This value can be used to check whether an entry needs to be updated because the source file was modified since it was last compressed.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntryCollection.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Adds an entry to the current zip file.
member.param: Name of the file to add to the zip file.
member.remarks: By default, the directory name is not stored in the zip file. To store a specific part of the directory name in the zip file, use the overloaded version of the Add method with a pathLevels parameter.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntryCollection.Add(System.String[])
member.summary: Adds a list of entries to the current zip file.
member.param: Array containing the file names of the entries to be added to the zip file.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntryCollection.Add(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an entry to the current zip file.
member.param: Name of the file to add to the zip file.
The number of path levels to be stored as the entry name.

remarks.para: By default, path names are not stored in the zip file. For example, adding the file "c:\temp\samples\readme.txt" to the zip file will create an entry called "readme.txt".

The parameter allows you to store one or more levels of the path in the entry name. For example, adding the file "c:\temp\samples\readme.txt" to the zip file with =1 will create an entry called "samples\readme.txt".

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipEntryCollection.Add(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds an entry to the current zip file.
member.param: Name of the file to add to the zip file.
Name of the new entry as stored in the zip file.
member.remarks: By default, entries in the zip file have the same name as the original (uncompressed) file. This method allows you to specify a different name, including a path for example.

member.summary: Adds a stream to the current zip file.
member.param: Stream that contains data for the new entry.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and creates or opens a zip file associated with this new instance.
member.param: The name of the zip file to open or create.
True to create a new zip file, false to open an existing file.

remarks.para: If is true, a new zip file is created. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten with a new empty file.
If is false, an existing zip file is opened. If the file does not exist, a new empty file is created.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and opens a zip file associated with this new instance.
member.param: The name of the zip file to open.
member.remarks: If the file does not exist, a new empty file is created.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Open(System.String)
member.summary: Opens an existing zip file.
member.param: The name of an existing zip file, including the path.

remarks.para: This method checks that the zip file exists and is a valid zip file, then reads the zip file directory into the collection. The zip file is then closed, and can be used by other applications. There is no need to close the zip file explicitly.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Close
member.summary: Resets all data members of the object.
member.remarks: Disk files are automatically closed by C1Zip. You only need to use this method if you want to break the connection between a class and a physical zip file.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Create(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an empty zip file on disk.
member.param: The name of the zip file to create, including the path.
member.remarks: If a file by the same name already exists, it is deleted before the new one is created.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Refresh
member.summary: Refreshes all data members by re-opening the current zip file.
member.remarks: This method is useful in instances where other applications may have changed the zip file and you want to make sure the information in the collection is up to date.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.IsZipFile(System.String)
member.summary: Tests whether a file is a valid zip file.
member.param: Name of the file to test.
member.returns: True if the file exists and is a valid zip file, false otherwise.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.OpenBatch
member.summary: Opens the zip file for multiple operations.

remarks.para: By default, opens and closes the zip file automatically whenever entries are added or removed.

This can cause delays in systems that have certain types of anti-virus software installed, or in situations where you want to add a large number of relatively small entries. In these cases, use the and methods to keep the zip file open until the entire operation is concluded.
Use a finally clause to ensure that the method is called even if an exception occurs.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.CloseBatch
member.summary: Closes a zip file after it was opened with a call to the method.
member.remarks: See the method for a complete description and a sample.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.FileName
member.summary: Gets the name of the current zip file.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the password to use when adding or retrieving entries from the zip file.

remarks.para: If the property is set to a non-empty string, any entries added to the zip file will be encrypted and protected by the password. To extract these entries later, the same password must be used.
The password applies to all entries from the moment it is set. If you set the password to a non-empty string and then add several entries to the zip file, all entries will use the same password.

Although C1Zip supports Unicode characters in passwords, several popular zip utilities do not. To ensure your encrypted zip files can be opened with third-party utilities, use passwords that consist of ASCII characters only.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Comment
member.summary: Gets or sets a comment associated with the current zip file.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.CompressionLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the compression level to use when adding entries to the zip file.
member.remarks: Higher compression settings create smaller files, but take longer to process. The default setting () provides a good trade-off between compression and speed.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.Entries
member.summary: Gets a that contains the entries in the zip file.
member.remarks: The collection is used to enumerate the entries in the zip file, and also to add, remove, and expand entries.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.OverwriteReadOnly
member.summary: Determines whether the component should overwrite read-only files when extracting entries from the zip file.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.OverwriteHidden
member.summary: Determines whether the component should overwrite hidden files when extracting entries from the zip file.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.OverwriteSystem
member.summary: Determines whether the component should overwrite system files when extracting entries from the zip file.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.MemoryThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the largest stream to be compressed in memory.

remarks.para: compresses entries into temporary streams before adding them to the zip file.
Entries with fewer than bytes are compressed using a temporary memory stream.
Entries with more than bytes are compressed using a temporary file. You can control the location of the temporary file using the property.

member.name: P:C1.C1Zip.C1ZipFile.TempFileName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the temporary file to use when adding entries to the zip file.
member.remarks: creates temporary streams while adding entries to a zip file. These temporary streams can be memory-based or disk-based, depending on the size of the entry and on the setting of the property. If a temporary file is used, you can control its location by setting the property. If you don't select a path for the temporary file, will create one automatically using the method.

member.name: T:C1.C1Zip.ZipEncoding
member.summary:
Encoding used for entry names and comments
NOTE: this is culture-dependent, which is a really bad idea, but most zip packers use the default OEM codepage to encode file names, so we have to go along with it...
Note that Encoding.Default seems like a logical choice but doesn't really work for international locales. Instead, we need to create an encoding using the current OEMCodePage. That allows accents and international characters to be used in file names (like the zip built into Windows, allows names such as "ﾅland.txt", "ﾄiti.txt", "W・th.txt", etc.).
This has nothing to do with compression, it's just used to encode and decode entry names and comments.

member.name: T:C1.C1Zip.ZipEntryStreamWriter
member.summary: ZipEntryStreamWriter Extends C1ZStreamWriter to provide the following: 1) Creates a memory or temporary storage stream. 2) Keeps track of the parent zip file. 3) Overrides Close to add the compressed stream to the zip file.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZStreamWriter.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Output stream that will contain the compressed data.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZStreamWriter.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Output stream that will contain the compressed data.
Specifies whether the compressed stream should be compatible with zip files.

remarks.para: Streams in zip files are different from regular zlib streams in two aspects:
(1) zip streams do not contain any local header information (the information is stored in the zip file headers instead) and
(2) zip streams use a CRC32 checksum instead of the adler32 checksum used by zlib streams.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.C1ZStreamWriter.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Output stream that will contain the compressed data.
Include header information in compressed stream (should be False for streams in zip files).
Include CRC32 checksum in compressed stream (should be True for streams in zip files).

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1BarCode.BarDirectionEnum
member.summary: Specifies the direction of the barcode

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.BarDirectionEnum.Normal
member.summary: The barcode is rendered in the horizontal direction.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.BarDirectionEnum.Up
member.summary: The barcode is rendered from the bottom up.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.BarDirectionEnum.Down
member.summary: The barcode is rendered from the top down.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum
member.summary: Specifies the type of barcode to be generated by the C1BarCode control.

remarks.para: The enumeration represents the different types of barcode that can be generated by the control.
Some types of barcode can be used to represent alphanumeric values, others can only represent numeric values.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Code39
member.summary: Code 39 is an alpha-numeric encoding also known as 3 of 9 and LOGMARS. This was the first alphanumeric symbology developed, and is one of the most widely used encodings.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Code93
member.summary: Code 93 is an alpha-numeric encoding that is slightly denser than code 39.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Code128
member.summary: Code 128 is a very high density alpha-numeric bar code. It will use the least amount of space of any current 1-D symbology for symbols with 6 characters or more.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.CodeI2of5
member.summary: Code I2of5 is a numeric encoding. The symbol can be as long as necessary to store the encoded data.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Codabar
member.summary: Codabar may encode 16 different characters (0 through 9 plus -$:/.+), plus an additional 4 start/stop characters (A through D). Codabar is used by some US blood banks, photo labs, and on FedEx airbills.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.PostNet
member.summary: PostNet is a numeric encoding used by the US postal service. It differs from most others in that it is based on the height of the bars rather than on their width.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Ean13
member.summary: EAN-13 was implemented by the International Article Numbering Association (EAN) in Europe. EAN-13 encodes a 12-digit code that consists of a 2 digit system code followed by a 5 digit manufacturer code and a 5-digit product code. The 12-digit code is followed by a checksum digit (automatically added by the control).

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.Ean8
member.summary: EAN-8 provides a short barcode for small packages. It encodes a 7-digit code that consists of a 2 or 3 digit system code followed by a 4 or 5 digit product code. The 7-digit code is followed by a checksum digit (automatically added by the control).

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1BarCode.CodeTypeEnum.UpcA
member.summary: UPC-A is the the common encoding you will find on virtually every consumer good on the shelves of your local supermarket, as well as books, magazines, and newspapers. It is similar to EAN-13, and encodes 11 digits of numeric data along with a trailing check digit.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode
member.summary: Creates barcode representations of alphanumeric values.

remarks.para: To use the C1BarCode control, set the property to the type of encoding you want to use, then set the property to the value you want to encode.
The control will show the barcode image. If you want to include the barcode in a document, use the property to retrieve a resolution-independent image of the barcode.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the control.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.GetImage(System.Drawing.Imaging.ImageFormat)
member.summary: Gets an image of the barcode that represents the value in the property, obtained using the encoding specified by the property.
member.param: An value that specifies the type of image to be created.
member.returns: An image of the barcode with the specified format.
member.remarks: The property can also be used to obtain an image of the barcode. However, it always returns a image of a pre-set size and with a transparent background. This method returns solid-background bitmaps.

member.returns: An image of the barcode with the specified format and dimensions.
member.remarks: The property can also be used to obtain an image of the barcode. However, it always returns a image of a pre-set size and with a transparent background. This method returns solid-background bitmaps.

member.summary: Gets or sets the background color for the control.
member.remarks: The background color only applies to the control. The barcode image that is available through the property always has a transparent background.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.ForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the foreground color for the control.
member.remarks: The foreground color applies to the control and also to the barcode image that is available through the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.Font
member.summary: Gets or sets the Font used to display the value of the Text property.
member.remarks: If the property is set to true, then the value of the property is displayed centered along the bottom of the barcode image using the given font.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.ShowText
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the value of the Text property should be displayed along with the barcode image.
member.remarks: By default, the control will show only the barcode image. To include a textual representation of the value in the property, set the property to True and set the property to the Font to be used for the textual display.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the value that is encoded as a barcode image.

remarks.para: Some encodings support alpha-numeric values of any length. Others are limited to numeric values or to a specific set of characters. See the enumeration for details.
If you use characters that are invalid for the current encoding, the control will display a blank image.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.CodeType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of encoding to use when generating the barcode image.
member.remarks: The selected encoding is applied to the value stored in the property to generate the barcode image displayed in the control. The barcode image is also available through the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.BarNarrow
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the narrow bars in screen pixels.
member.remarks: By default, narrow bars are one screen pixel wide (1/96") and wide bars are two pixels wide (1/96"). You should never have to change these values, they are exposed only in case you need to make adjustments for special barcode reader hardware.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.BarWide
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the wide bars in screen pixels.
member.remarks: By default, narrow bars are one screen pixel wide (1/96") and wide bars are two pixels wide (1/96"). You should never have to change these values, they are exposed only in case you need to make adjustments for special barcode reader hardware.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.BarHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of the bars in screen pixels.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.SizeMode
member.summary: Gets or sets how the barcode image is displayed within the control.

remarks.para: This property only affects how the barcode is displayed within the control. It has no effect on the actual barcode image, as returned by the property.
In most applications, you will either center or left-align the barcode image within the control. Although stretching the image is possible, it may make it unreadable for some barcode readers.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.BarDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of the barcode.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1BarCode.C1BarCode.Image
member.summary: Gets an image of the barcode that represents the value in the property, obtained using the encoding specified by the property.

remarks.para: The Image property returns a that can be inserted in reports and other documents. If the value stored in the property is invalid for the current encoding, the image returned is blank.

Although the barcode image returned by the control is scalable, the default size is optimal for common barcode readers. Keep in mind that if you stretch the image and make it very large or very small, it may become unreadable to some readers.
The metafile image has a transparent background and therefore cannot be easily converted to a solid-background bitmap. To obtain a image of the barcode, use the method instead.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.Load(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads a list of the worksheets in an xls file, optionally skipping the data contained in the sheets.
member.param: Name of the xls file to load.
True to read the sheet data, false to read only the sheet names.
member.remarks: Loading the worksheets without their data is much faster than loading the entire workbook. This is useful in situations where you want to examine the contents of the xls file (for example, to ensure that you will not overwrite an existing sheet).

member.param: Name of the xls file to save.
member.remarks: If the file can't be created, an exception will be thrown. This typically indicates that the file is currently open by another application (such as Microsoft Excel).

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.PixelsToTwips(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a pixel measurement into twips (1/20th of a point).
member.param: Measurement in screen pixels.
member.returns: Measurement in twips.

remarks.para: Excel stores measurements in twips (1/20th of a point), a resolution-independent unit. .NET controls, on the other hand, usually express measurements in pixels. This method provides an easy way to convert pixel measurements into twips using the current screen resolution.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.TwipsToPixels(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a twip measurement into screen pixels.
member.param: Measurement in twips.
member.returns: Measurement in screen pixels.

remarks.para: Excel stores measurements in twips (1/20th of a point), a resolution-independent unit. .NET controls, on the other hand, usually express measurements in pixels. This method provides an easy way to convert pixel measurements into twips using the current screen resolution.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.Sheets
member.summary: Gets a collection of objects that represent the worksheets in the .
member.remarks: The returned has methods for counting, enumerating, adding and removing sheets from the .

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.DefaultFont
member.summary: Gets or sets the default for the .

remarks.para: You can assign any font to any cell using objects. Cells that have no associated custom styles or have styles that do not define a custom font are displayed using the book's default font.
The property is initially set to 10 pt Arial.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.C1XLBook.KeepFormulas
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should store formulas read from Xls files and write them back when saving the file.

remarks.para: Setting this property to true allows you to load existing XLS files, modify the values in some cells, and save the file preserving the formulas. This is the default setting.

Setting this property to false causes the component to remove the formulas in the book when it is loaded. Saving the file in this case will retain the last calculated values but will remove the formulas.
The component does not provide any support for creating or editing formulas. Formulas must be created in Excel.
Assigning any value to a cell will clear the formula in the cell.

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.BuiltInFormats
member.summary: Summary description for BuiltInFormats.

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.XLCell
member.summary: Represents individual cells in a , and provides properties for getting and setting the cell , , and .

remarks.para: To create cells, use the indexer (Item property). If the cell already exists, the reference will be returned as usual. If not, the sheet will create the cell (as well as rows and columns if necessary) and will return a reference to the new cell.
Because it creates cells automatically, the indexer is especially useful when creating and populating sheets.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.XLCell.SetValue(System.Object,C1.C1Excel.XLStyle)
member.summary: Sets the and properties of a cell.
member.param: New cell value.
New cell style.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLCell.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value stored in the cell.

remarks.para: The value may contain strings, numeric, boolean, , or null objects. Other types of object can't be saved into Excel files.

DateTime values are internally converted into doubles, and stored in the sheet as such. The only way to tell the difference between a DateTime value and a double in Excel is by way of the format associated with the cell ( property).

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLCell.Style
member.summary: Gets or sets the object associated with the cell.

remarks.para: The appearance of each cell is defined by one or more XLStyle objects.
When displaying a cell, Excel combines the row, column, and cell styles and merges the style elements defined in each one in order to determine how the cell should be displayed.

The precedence of the styles is: (1) cell, (2) row, (3) column, (4) default style. For example, if a cell style defines the font and background color, those will be applied regardless of the settings in the row and column styles. If the row style defines an alignment, that will be applied regardless of the column style, and so on.
The cell style may be null, in which case the cell is displayed using the other styles available or the default book style if no others are available.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLCell.Hyperlink
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that specifies an action to take when the cell is clicked.

remarks.para: Hyperlinks may contain URLs that when clicked open a browser window and navigate to the specified site (for example, "http://www.componentone.com"). They may also contain references to files that are launched by the application associated with the file type (for example, "readme.doc"). Finally, hyperlinks can be used to send e-mails (for example, "mailto:joe@foo.com").
Each cell may contain a hyperlink and a value. However, if you assign a hyperlink to a cell that has no value ( == null), then the hyperlink text is automatically assigned to the cell value as well.

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings
member.summary: Provides options and settings for printing objects.

remarks.para: The settings are applied to each sheet, and are accessible through the sheet's property.
Note that does not provide any printing services. The settings are used when printing the sheet from Excel.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.Header
member.summary: Gets or sets the string to be displayed as a page header when the sheet is printed.
member.remarks:
The header string may contain special commands, i.e. placeholders for the page number, current date, or text formatting attributes. Most of these fields are represented by single letters with a leading ampersand ("&").
The page header is divided into 3 sections: left, center, and right. Each section is introduced by a special command ("&L", "&C", and "&R"). All text and all commands following are part of the selected section.
The following commands are available:
&L Start of the left section
&C Start of the centred section
&R Start of the right section
&P Current page number
&N Page count
&D Current date
&T Current time
&A Sheet name
&F File name without path
&Z File path without file name
&G Picture (file name)
&B Bold toggle
&I Italic toggle
&U Underline toggle
&E Double underle toggle
&S Strikeout toggle
&X Superscript toggle
&Y Subscript toggle
&"[fontname]" Set new font
&"[fontname,fontstyle]" Set new font with specified style. The style is in most cases "Regular", "Bold", "Italic", or "Bold Italic". &[fontheight] Set font height in points.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.Footer
member.summary: Gets or sets the string to be displayed as a page header when the sheet is printed.
member.remarks: The footer string has the same structure and embedded commands as the header string. See the property for details.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.CenterHorizontal
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the sheet should be centered horizontally on the page when printed.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.CenterVertical
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the sheet should be centered vertically on the page when printed.

member.summary: Gets or sets the left margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.MarginRight
member.summary: Gets or sets the right margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.summary: Gets or sets the top margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.MarginBottom
member.summary: Gets or sets the bottom margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.MarginHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets the header margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.MarginFooter
member.summary: Gets or sets the footer margin, in inches. Set to a negative value to use the default margin.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.PrintHeaders
member.summary: Gets or sets whether row and column headers (the areas with row numbers and column letters) will be printed.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.PrintGridlines
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the gridlines will be printed.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.PaperKind
member.summary: Gets or sets the paper size to use when printing the sheet.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.ScalingFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling factor (in percent) to use when printing the sheet.
member.remarks: Setting the property automatically sets the property to false, causing C1Excel to use the selected scaling factor and to ignore the value of the and properties.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.AutoScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling mode used for printed output.

remarks.para: If is set to true, then the printed sheet will be automatically scaled to fit the number of pages specified by the and properties.
If is set to false, then the printed sheet will be scaled according to the value of the property.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.StartPage
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial page number to use when printing the sheet.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.FitPagesAcross
member.summary: Fit the sheet to this number of pages across (0 means use as many as needed).
member.remarks: Causes C1Excel to select "fit to page" print mode, ignoring the value of the property. Setting the or properties automatically sets the property to true, causing C1Excel to calculate the scaling factor based on the given number of pages and to ignore the value of the property.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.FitPagesDown
member.summary: Fit the sheet to this number of pages down (0 means use as many as needed).
member.remarks: Setting the or properties automatically sets the property to true, causing C1Excel to calculate the scaling factor based on the given number of pages and to ignore the value of the property.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.Copies
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of copies to print.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.PrintPagesInRows
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to print the pages in rows (across first) or in columns (down first).

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.Landscape
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to print the sheet in landscape mode.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to print the sheet in monochrome mode.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLPrintSettings.DraftQuality

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet
member.summary: Represents individual worksheets in an Excel workbook ().
member.remarks: Provides indexers to get or set the value of individual cells () and to access the and on the sheet.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.GetCell(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a reference to a cell at the specified coordinates, or null of the cell doesn't exist.
member.param: Index of the row.
Index of the column.
member.returns: A reference to the object at the specified coordinates, or null if there is no cell at the specified position.

remarks.para: To populate new sheets, use the indexer instead.
The indexer will automatically create new rows, columns, and cells as needed, and will never return null.

member.name: M:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Clone
member.summary: Creates a copy of this sheet.
member.returns: A new object with the same contents and formatting as this sheet.

remarks.para: After cloning a sheet, you must rename it and then add it to the book (duplicate names are not allowed).
This method is useful for applications that generate books with a large number of similar sheets.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Book
member.summary: Gets a reference to the that owns the sheet.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the .

remarks.para: When you open a workbook in Excel, the sheet names appear in the tabs below the work area.
Sheet names can be used as indexers, so they should be unique.

member.summary: Gets a that contains the collection of cells that are merged on the sheet.
member.remarks: The collection has methods for inspecting, adding, or clearing merged ranges in a sheet. Each merged range is represented by a object.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.DefaultRowHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the default row height for the sheet (in twips).

remarks.para: You can set the height of individual rows using the class. Any rows that do not have a custom height assigned to them will be displayed using the sheet's .
The property is expressed in twips (1/20th of a point), rather than pixels. This allows sheets to maintain their aspect regardless of the resolution of the display.
To convert twips into pixels, use the method in . To convert pixels into twips, use the method.

The property is expressed in twips (1/20th of a point), rather than pixels. This allows sheets to maintain their aspect regardless of the resolution of the display.
To convert twips into pixels, use the method in . To convert pixels into twips, use the method.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the cell at a specified position on the sheet, creating a new cell if necessary.

remarks.para: If the specified cell doesn't exist when the indexer is invoked, the sheet will be expanded and a new cell will be created, then returned. This makes it easy to create and populate sheets.
If you want to determine whether a specific cell has been defined, use the method instead.
The indexer is generally more useful when creating and populating sheets. The method is more useful when loading existing sheets.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Locked
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines if the sheet is locked for editing.

remarks.para: Sheets and styles can be locked. By default, sheets are unlocked and styles are locked. This combination allows users to edit the cells in Excel.
To protect a cell against editing in Excel, both the sheet and the cell style must have the property set to true.
To lock most cells on a sheet and allow editing of only a few cells, lock the sheet, then create an unlocked style and assign it to the cells that should be editable.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets the sheet's visibility.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLSheet.GridColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used to display gridlines.

remarks.para: Set this property to Color.Transparent to dispaly the grid lines using the default color.
To hide the grid lines, set the property to false.

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.SharedStringTable
member.summary:
SharedStringTable is an ArrayList that contains a Hashtable helper.
The Hashtable contains pairs (string, index) and is used for two purposes:
1) To prevent the addition of duplicate values to the list. The Add method looks up values in the hashtable and only adds new values.
2) To provide a quick IndexOf override. The index is retrieved from the Hashtable instead of using the slow default linear search.
This new implementation reduces the time needed to save a 10,000 x 20 sheet from 650 seconds down to 16, essentially the same amount of time needed to save numbers.

member.name: T:C1.C1Excel.XLStyle
member.summary: Contains style elements used to define the appearance of the cells.

remarks.para: Each object may define one or more of the following elements: font, format, background color, background pattern, foreground color, alignment, text direction, and word wrapping.

When displaying a cell, Excel combines the row, column, and cell styles and merges the style elements defined in each one in order to determine how the cell should be displayed. The precedence of the styles is: (1) cell, (2) row, (3) column, (4) default style.
Every belongs to a , and may be assigned to one or more , , and objects through their property.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLStyle.ForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the foreground color for this .

remarks.para: Set the property to Color.Transparent to suppress this style element and use the default foreground color instead (black).

All colors on the are mapped onto a palette. This means that is you assign colors to styles, save the book, and then load it back, you probably won't get exactly the same colors used when the book was created. You will get a fairly close approximation though.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLStyle.BackColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color for this .

remarks.para: Set the property to Color.Transparent to suppress this style element and use the default background color instead (white).

All colors on the are mapped onto a palette. This means that is you assign colors to styles, save the book, and then load it back, you probably won't get exactly the same colors used when the book was created. You will get a fairly close approximation though.

member.summary: Gets or sets the format associated with this .

remarks.para: Excel uses formats similar, but not identical to .NET. Refer to the Excel documentation for details on how to create format strings.
You can use the and methods to convert common Excel format strings to and from .NET format strings.

member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal alignment for this .
member.remarks: Set the property to to suppress this style element and use the default horizontal alignment instead ().

member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical alignment for this .
member.remarks: Set the property to to suppress this style element and use the default horizontal alignment instead ().

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLStyle.WordWrap
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this causes cell contents to wrap.
member.remarks: Cells that do not wrap will spill onto adjacent cells, and will be kept on a single line even if they contain line-break characters.

member.name: P:C1.C1Excel.XLStyle.Rotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation for this , in degrees.

remarks.para: This property should be set to values between 0 and 180, or 255, as explained below:
Zero means no rotation.
1-90 means 1 to 90 degrees counter-clockwise (90 causes text to be displayed in the vertical direction going up the cell).
91-180 means 1 to 90 degrees clockwise (180 causes text to be displayed in the vertical direction going down the cell).
255 causes letters are stacked top to bottom and not rotated.

member.summary: Draws the specified text string in the specified rectangle with the specified and objects using the formatting attributes of the specified object.
member.param: String to draw.
object that defines the appearance and size of the drawn text.
object that defines the color of the drawn text.
structure that specifies the location of the drawn text, in points from the top left corner of the page.
object that specifies formatting attributes applied to the drawn text.
Index of the first character that will be rendered.
member.returns: The index of first character that was not printed because it did not fit in the specified rectangle.

remarks.para: The contains properties that specify formatting options. Use the property to specify horizontal alignment and the property to specify vertical alignment.
Use the property to specify clipping and wrapping.

To render text in the vertical direction, use the . By itself, this flag will cause text to render from the bottom to the top of the rectangle. Combined with the flags, it will cause text to render from the top to the bottom of the rectangle.

The DrawString method returns the index of the first character that was not printed because it did not fit the output rectangle. You can use this value make text flow from page to page, or from one frame to another within a page.

member.name: M:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.DrawStringRtf(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Draws an Rtf string in the specified rectangle with the specified and objects.
member.param: Rtf string to draw.
object that defines the appearance and size of the drawn text.
object that defines the color of the drawn text.
structure that specifies the location of the drawn text, in points from the top left corner of the page.
member.returns: The index of first character that was not printed because it did not fit in the specified rectangle, or the value of int.MaxValue if the entire string was rendered.

remarks.para: This method is similar to , except it recognizes Rtf (Rich Text Format) strings like those used in the control.
There are two types of Rtf strings:

1) Complete Rtf strings contain an Rtf header that specifies the fonts and colors used within the string. These strings can be obtained from a control using the property, or from Rtf files saved to disk. In this case, the and parameters are not used.

2) Partial Rtf strings contain embedded Rtf tags but no Rtf header. These strings are easy to build in code and can be used to render text with special attributes such as bold and italics (for example: "this text contains {\b BOLD} and {\i ITALICS}". In this case, the and parameters are used to build the Rtf header automatically.

The DrawStringRtf method returns the index of the first character that was not printed because it did not fit the output rectangle. You can use this value make text flow from page to page, or from one frame to another within a page. To do this, use the overload that takes the starting character in the text as a parameter.

member.name: M:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.DrawStringRtf(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Int32)
member.summary: Draws an Rtf string in the specified rectangle with the specified and objects, starting at a given offset within the string.
member.param: Rtf string to draw.
object that defines the appearance and size of the drawn text.
object that defines the color of the drawn text.
structure that specifies the location of the drawn text, in points from the top left corner of the page.
Index of the first character to draw (usually the return value of a previous call to DrawStringRtf).
member.returns: The index of first character that was not printed because it did not fit in the specified rectangle, or the value of int.MaxValue if the entire string was rendered.

remarks.para: This method is similar to , except it recognizes Rtf (Rich Text Format) strings like those used in the control.
There are two types of Rtf strings:

1) Complete Rtf strings contain an Rtf header that specifies the fonts and colors used within the string. These strings can be obtained from a control using the property, or from Rtf files saved to disk. In this case, the and parameters are not used.

2) Partial Rtf strings contain embedded Rtf tags but no Rtf header. These strings are easy to build in code and can be used to render text with special attributes such as bold and italics (for example: "this text contains {\b BOLD} and {\i ITALICS}". In this case, the and parameters are used to build the Rtf header automatically.

The DrawStringRtf method returns the index of the first character that was not printed because it did not fit the output rectangle. You can use this value make text flow from page to page, or from one frame to another within a page. Note that this value is not an index into the raw Rtf input, but into the text represented by the Rtf. See example below.

member.name: M:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.AddBookmark(System.String,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds a bookmark to the current page.
member.param: Text that appears on the outline tree.
Outline level (zero is the top level).
Position on the current page where the outline entry is located (in points).
member.remarks: Most long Pdf documents contain an outline structure that is displayed on a pane on the left of the reader. The outline makes it easy to browse through a document's structure and find specific topics. The method allows you to build this outline structure by adding outline entries (bookmarks).

member.name: M:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.AddLink(System.String,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Adds a hyperlink to the current page.
member.param: Link destination (can be a url, a file name, or a local link destination).
Area on the page that will behave as a link (expressed in points, from the top-left corner of the page).

member.name: M:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.AddLink(System.String,System.Int32,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Adds a hyperlink to the document.
member.param: Link destination (can be a url, a file name, or a local link destination).
Index of the page that contains the hyperlink
Area on the page that will behave as a link (expressed in points, from the top-left corner of the page).

remarks.para: Hyperlinks can be external (urls and file names) or local (other locations within the same document).

Local links are useful when you want to implement some type of cross-referencing within the document, such as a table of contents or an index. Local links are identical to regular hyperlinks, except for two things:
1) The parameter must start with a "#", and
2) You must specify the target location for the link using the method.

Note that the method does not add any visible content to the page, so you will usually need another command along with to specify some text or an image that the user can see, as the example below demonstrates.

member.param: Name of the target (used in the method).
Area on the page that will behave as a target (in points from the top-left corner of the page).
member.remarks: This method is used to add targets for local hyperlinks. See the method for details and an example.

member.name: P:C1.C1Pdf.C1PdfDocument.CurrentPage
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the current page within the document.

remarks.para: The property determines which page of the document should receive the output from the methods that generate content (e.g. ).
The value is an integer ranging from -1 (no active page) to .-1.

You rarely have to use the property while creating a document. When a object is created, a blank page is automatically added and becomes the current page, so you can immediately start adding content to it. When the method is invoked, a new page is added to the document and becomes the current page.
The property is useful when you want to reopen pages that have already been generated and add content to them (for example, page headers and footers).

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflateInit
member.summary: Initializes the internal stream state for decompression.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: The fields and must be initialized before by the caller.

inflateInit does not perform any decompression apart from reading the zlib header if present: data decompression is done by the method. Therefore, the next_in and avail_in may be modified, but next_out and avail_out are unchanged.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflateInit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the internal stream state for decompression.
member.param: Size of the LZ77 sliding compression window in bits (the default value is 15 bits).
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decompresses as much data as possible until the input buffer is exhausted or the output buffer is full.
member.param: How to flush data into the output buffer (default value is 2).
member.returns: Z_OK if some progress has been made (more input processed or more output produced), Z_STREAM_END if the end of the compressed data has been reached and all uncompressed output has been produced, Z_NEED_DICT if a preset dictionary is needed at this point, Z_DATA_ERROR if the input data was corrupted (input stream not conforming to the zlib format or incorrect checksum), Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream structure was inconsistent (for example if next_in or next_out was null), Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough memory, Z_BUF_ERROR if no progress is possible or if there was not enough room in the output buffer when Z_FINISH is used.

remarks.para: inflate performs one or both of the following actions:

1. Decompress more input starting at next_in and update next_in and avail_in accordingly. If not all input can be processed (because there is not enough room in the output buffer), next_in is updated and processing will resume at this point for the next call to inflate.

2. Provide more output starting at next_out and update next_out and avail_out accordingly. inflate provides as much output as possible, until there is no more input data or no more space in the output buffer.

Before the call to inflate, the application should ensure that at least one of the actions is possible, by providing more input and/or consuming more output, and updating the next_* and avail_* values accordingly.
If inflate returns Zero and avail_out == 0, it must be called again after making room in the output buffer because there might be more output pending.
The application can consume the uncompressed output when it wants, for example when the output buffer is full (avail_out == 0), or after each call of inflate.
This method may introduce some output latency (reading input without producing any output) except when forced to flush.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflateEnd
member.summary: Frees all dynamically allocated data structures for this stream, discards any unprocessed input, and does not flush any pending output.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflateSync
member.summary: Skips invalid compressed data until a full flush point is found, or until all available input is skipped. No output is provided.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.inflateSetDictionary(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the decompression dictionary from the given uncompressed byte sequence.
member.param: Data in the dictionary.
Number of bytes in the ditionary.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: This method must be called immediately after a call of if this call returned Z_NEED_DICT. The dictionary chosen by the compressor can be determined from the Adler32 value returned by this call to inflate.
The compressor and decompressor must use exactly the same dictionary (see the method).

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflateInit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the internal stream state for compression.
member.param: Compression level between zero and nine (0-9).
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: Compression level 1 gives best speed, 9 gives best compression.
Compression level zero gives no compression at all (the input data is simply copied a block at a time).
The default compression level is 6, which provides a compromise between speed and compression.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflateInit(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the internal stream state for compression.
member.param: Compression level between zero and nine (0-9).
Size of the LZ77 sliding compression window in bits (the default value is 15 bits).
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: Compression level 1 gives best speed, 9 gives best compression.
Compression level zero gives no compression at all (the input data is simply copied a block at a time).
The default compression level is 6, which provides a compromise between speed and compression.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Compresses as much data as possible, and stops when the input buffer becomes empty or the output buffer becomes full.
member.param: Non-zero to force some data to be flushed into the output buffer.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: deflate performs one or both of the following actions:

1. Compress more input starting at next_in and update next_in and avail_in accordingly. If not all input can be processed (because there is not enough room in the output buffer), next_in and avail_in are updated and processing will resume at this point for the next call to deflate.

2. Provide more output starting at next_out and update next_out and avail_out accordingly. This action is forced if the parameter is non zero. Forcing flush frequently degrades the compression ratio, so this parameter should be set only when necessary (in interactive applications). Some output may be provided even if flush is not set
This method may introduce some output latency (reading input without producing any output) except when forced to flush.
If deflate returns with avail_out == 0, this method must be called again with the same value of the parameter and more output space until the flush is complete (deflate returns with avail_out != 0).

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflateEnd
member.summary: Frees all dynamically allocated data structures for this stream, discards any unprocessed input, and does not flush any pending output.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflateParams(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Dynamically updates the compression level and compression strategy.
member.param: Compression level between zero and nine (0-9).
Compression strategy (0-2).

member.name: M:C1.C1Zip.ZLib.ZStream.deflateSetDictionary(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes the compression dictionary from the given byte sequence without producing any compressed output.
member.param: Data in the dictionary.
Number of bytes in the ditionary.
member.returns: Zero on success, an error code on failure.

remarks.para: This method must be called immediately after , before any call to .
The compressor and decompressor must use exactly the same dictionary (see ).

item.description: Anchor inside a previously saved C1D document.
External document, program or URL (the ShellExecute API is used to invoke the link).
Another page inside the current document.

member.summary: This class starts a new document when a hyperlink with this type of LinkTarget is clicked. When such a hyperlink is activated (clicked), the UserHyperlinkJump event is fired. This class does not have any public properties or methods of its own.

member.summary: Describes a link to an external document, file or URL. The link is performed using the ShellExecute API.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.C1LinkTargetFile.FileName
member.summary: Specifies the file or object on which to execute the specified verb.
member.remarks: To specify a Shell namespace object, pass the fully qualified parse name. Note that not all verbs are supported on all objects. For example, not all document types support the "print" verb.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.C1LinkTargetFile.Command
member.summary: String, referred to in this case as a verb, that specifies the action to be performed.

remarks.para: The set of available verbs depends on the particular file or folder. Generally, the actions available from an object's shortcut menu are available verbs.
For more information about verbs and their availability, see Object Verbs. See Extending Shortcut Menus for further discussion of shortcut menus.
The following verbs are commonly used.

list.item: edit Launches an editor and opens the document for editing. If FileName is not a document file, the function will fail.

item.description: Explores the folder specified by FileName.
Initiates a search starting from the specified directory.
Opens the file specified by the FileName parameter. The file can be an executable file, a document file, or a folder.
Prints the document file specified by FileName. If FileName is not a document file, the function will fail.

For systems prior to Microsoft? Windows? 2000, the default verb is used if it is valid and available in the registry. If not, the "open" verb is used. For Windows 2000 and later systems, the default verb is used if available. If not, the "open" verb is used. If neither verb is available, the system uses the first verb listed in the registry.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.C1LinkTargetFile.Parameters
member.summary: If the FileName parameter specifies an executable file, Parameters is a string that specifies the parameters to be passed to the application. The format of this string is determined by the verb that is to be invoked. If FileName specifies a document file, Parameters should be an empty string.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.C1LinkTargetFile.Directory
member.summary: String that specifies the default directory.

member.summary: Base for a simple type converter to/from strings.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.StackingRulesEnum
member.summary: Defines the stacking rules: block flow or inline flow, LeftToRight or TopToBottom.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.StackingRulesEnum.BlockTopToBottom
member.summary: Objects are placed one beneath the other within the container. When the bottom edge of the current page is reached, a new page is added. This is the default.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.StackingRulesEnum.BlockLeftToRight
member.summary: Objects are placed one next to another, from left to right. When the right edge of the current page is reached, a new horizontal page is added (a horizontal page logically extends the preceding page to the right; C1PreviewPane respects this location by default, showing such pages in a row).

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.StackingRulesEnum.InlineLeftToRight
member.summary: Objects are placed inline, one next to another, from left to right. When the right edge of the current page is reached, the sequence wraps to the next line. A new page is added when the bottom of the current page is reached.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.PrinterUtil.FindBestPrinter(System.Single,System.Single@)
member.summary: Searches for the printer with specified minimal dpi, the horizontal and vertical dpi of printer must be same.
member.param: The minimal possible dpi. If this parameter is zero then the first printer with "square" dpi will be selected.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.SplitBehaviorEnum
member.summary: Defines the splitting behavior of a render object.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.SplitBehaviorEnum.Never
member.summary: The object should not be split between pages (i.e. should always be kept together on a single page).

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.SplitBehaviorEnum.SplitIfNeeded
member.summary: The object can be split if it does not fit onto the current page.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.SplitBehaviorEnum.SplitIfLarge
member.summary: The object can be split only if it is too large to fit on an empty page. In that case, the object is split immediately. Otherwise, a new page is started and the object is placed on it without splitting.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.SplitBehaviorEnum.SplitNewPage
member.summary: If the object does not fit on the current page (column), a new page (column) is started; if the object does not fit on that page (column), it is split as needed after that.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.BreakEnum
member.summary: Defines the various breaks which can be forced before or after render object.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.BreakEnum.None
member.summary: No break.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.BreakEnum.Page
member.summary: New page should be started.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.BreakEnum.Column
member.summary: New column should be started.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.BreakEnum.Line
member.summary: New line on inline flow should be started.

member.summary: Defines table sizing modes.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableSizingModeEnum.Default
member.summary: At table level, default is Auto for rows, and Fixed for columns; at row/column level, default inherits from the table.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableSizingModeEnum.Fixed
member.summary: Size (height for rows, width for columns) should be explicitly specified (if omitted, is determined by the available space and row/column count).

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableSizingModeEnum.Auto
member.summary: Size (height for rows, width for columns) is calculated automatically based on the content.

member.summary: The content of cell should be copied each time when it splits.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.CellSplitBehaviorEnum.Cut
member.summary: The content of cell should be cut on first time and displayed only once.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableHeaderEnum
member.summary: Defines how the table header is repeated.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableHeaderEnum.None
member.summary: The header is printed once at the top of the table.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableHeaderEnum.Page
member.summary: The header is repeated at the top of each page. If there are multiple columns per page, the header is repeated only at the top of the first column on the page.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableHeaderEnum.Column
member.summary: The header is repeated only if there are multiple columns per page, at the top of each column except the first on the page. If there is only one column, the header is not printed at all.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableHeaderEnum.All
member.summary: The header is repeated at the top of all pages. If there are multiple columns per page, the header is repeated at the top of each column.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableFooterEnum
member.summary: Defines how the table footer is repeated.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableFooterEnum.None
member.summary: The footer is printed once at the end of the table.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableFooterEnum.Page
member.summary: The footer is repeated at the bottom of each page. If there are multiple columns per page, the footer is repeated only at the bottom of the last column on the page.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableFooterEnum.Column
member.summary: The footer is repeated only if there are multiple columns per page, at the bottom of each column except the last on the page. If there is only one column, the footer is not printed at all.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableFooterEnum.All
member.summary: The footer is repeated at the bottom of all pages. If there are multiple columns per page, the footer is repeated at the bottom of each column.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.LastPosition
member.summary: Gets the number of column or row with which group ends.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.CanSplit
member.summary: Indicates whether the group can be split between pages.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.PageHeader
member.summary: Indicates whether the group should be reprinted as header on each page where table exists. Only one group in the table can has this flag.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.PageFooter
member.summary: Indicates whether the group should be reprinted as footer on each page where table exists. Only one group in the table can has this flag.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.ColumnHeader
member.summary: Indicates whether the group should be reprinted as header on each column where table exists. Only one group in the table can has this flag.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.ColumnFooter
member.summary: Indicates whether the group should be reprinted as footer on each column where table exists. Only one group in the table can has this flag.

member.summary: Gets the index of column or row from which groups begins.

member.name: P:C1.C1PreviewClient.TableVectorGroup.LastNumber

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.LengthBase
member.summary: Represents a simple coordinate or size of object. This is an abstract class.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.LengthBase.StringToUnitType(System.String,C1.C1PreviewClient.UnitTypeEnum@)
member.summary: Converts a string to a UnitTypeEnum value. The string can be one of the following: "def", "doc", "in", "mm", "pc", "pix", "pt", "tw", "inhs". This method is case-insensitive.
member.param: The string to convert. If it is null or empty, units are set to UnitTypeEnum.Default.
On exit, contains the UnitTypeEnum value.
member.returns: Returns true if no error occurs, false otherwise.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.LengthBase.UnitTypeToString(C1.C1PreviewClient.UnitTypeEnum)
member.summary:
Converts a UnitTypeEnum value to the string representation.
DefaultEmpty string
Document"doc"
Inch"in"
Millimeter"mm"
Pica"pc"
Pixel"pix"
Point"pt"
Twip"tw"
InHs"inhs"
member.param: Value to convert.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.LengthBase.StringToDimension(System.String,C1.C1PreviewClient.DimensionEnum@)
member.summary: Converts a string to DimensionEnum. String can have value from: ("left", "top", "right", "bottom", "width", "height", "relleft", "reltop", "relright", "relbottom"). Method is case insensitive.
member.param: String to convert, if s is null or empty then units will be RefDim.Default.
Contains a dimension on exit.
member.returns: Returns true if no error occurs.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.LengthBase.Parse(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Analyzes a passed string and creates an instance of the LengthBase class on the basis of this string.
member.param: String to analyze.
Indicates whether an exception must be raised if string has an error and can't be converted to the LengthBase.
member.returns: Returns an instance LengthAbs or LengthRef or LengthExp or LengthAuto class, returns a null value if throwException equals false and s has an error.

member.name: T:C1.C1PreviewClient.Utils
member.summary: Contains common functions.

member.name: F:C1.C1PreviewClient.Utils.FloatFormatInfo
member.summary: The special NumberFormatInfo object used to convert numbers in C1PrintDocument, its fields are initialized as: NumberDecimalSeparator is "." CurrencyDecimalSeparator is "."

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.Utils.IndexInArray(System.String[],System.String)
member.summary: Returns the index of string in array of strings. Search is case sensitive.
member.param: Array of strings.
String to search.
member.returns: Index of string in array of -1.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.Utils.TryParseInt(System.String,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its 32-bit signed integer equivalent. A return value indicates whether the operation succeeded. This functions uses FloatFormatInfo as format provider.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the 32-bit signed integer value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format, or represents a number less than MinValue or greater than MaxValue. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:C1.C1PreviewClient.Utils.TryParseDouble(System.String,System.Double@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its double-precision floating-point number equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed. This functions uses FloatFormatInfo as format provider.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains a double-precision floating-point number equivalent to the numeric value or symbol contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in a format compliant with style, represents a number less than MinValue or greater than MaxValue, or if style is not a valid combination of NumberStyles enumerated constants. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.returns: Array of colors or null if s is null.

member.summary: Converts a string to array of floats.

member.returns: Array of floats or null if s is null.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource
member.summary: Provides data for reports.

remarks.para: Most reports specify their data sources by setting the and properties. The DataSource object uses these values to connect to a database and retrieve the report data.

Alternatively, you can assign data objects directly to the property. This approach is more efficient in scenarios where the data has already been loaded by the application for other purposes, and can be used in the report directly instead of loading a copy.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.GetRecordSource(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Processes the PARAMETERS clause in the string and returns the result.

remarks.para: This property is related to the property. The property sets or returns a string that specifies the source dataset for the report, and it may contain a PARAMETERS clause that causes to prompt the user for information.
If you wanted to use the value of the property to open a dataset directly from your program, you would have to parse the PARAMETERS clause yourself.

member.param: If set to true, user will be prompted for the parameters before the method returns. If set to false, the default values will be used.
member.returns: The string (SQL statement or table name) that can be used to open a recordset.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.ConnectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets the string used to open a database.

remarks.para: The is used by the class to load the report data.
The class uses an object to retrieve the data, so the syntax for the is the one used OleDb connection strings. For details on the syntax, see the documentation for the class.
The specifies the database that contains the report data. The property specifies which table, stored procedure, or Sql command to use for retrieveing the data.
If you want to use a different type of connection (e.g. a , or if your application already has the data available in a object, you can assign the data directly to the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.RecordSource
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that specifies which table, stored procedure, or Sql command to use for retrieving the report data.

remarks.para: The specifies the database that contains the report data. The property specifies which table, stored procedure, or Sql command to use for retrieveing the data.
If you want to use a different type of connection (e.g. a , or if your application already has the data available in a object, you can assign the data directly to the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.Filter
member.summary: Gets or sets the expression used to filter which data rows are included in the report.

remarks.para: Use the Filter property to restrict the records that you want to include in a report without modifying the property.

Using a filter is similar to specifying a WHERE clause in the SQL statement assigned to the property. Both techniques will filter the data according to the condidtion specified. The difference is that the Filter property is applied to a table that has already been loaded in memory, while the WHERE statement causes only the filtered records to be loaded from the database into memory.

When creating reports that include only small subsets large tables, the WHERE statement is a better option, because it doesn't require the entire table to be loaded into memory. On the other hand, if the table has already been loaded in memory, the Filter property is a better option, since it does not require any additional data to be loaded.

The syntax for the filter expression is the same used to specify the property for objects. The expressions consist of conditions in the form ColumnName Operator Value, where ColumnName is the name of a column in the data source (optionally enclosed in square brackets), Operator is one of the regular Visual Basic comparison operators, and Value is a literal enclosed in single quotes. Conditions may be concatenated using AND and OR operators.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.MaxRecords
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of data rows to be included in the report (set to zero to include all rows).

remarks.para: This property is useful if you want to limit the size of a report. For example, you may write a report designer with a preview window that shows only the first 500 records from the database.
Setting this property to zero causes the control to retrieve all records.
You can also limit the size of reports by setting the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.DataSource.Recordset
member.summary: Sets or gets the data source object that provides data to the report.

remarks.para: Usually, the control creates a object based on the value of the and properties, and uses that object as the report data source.
Alternatively, you may want to create the data source object yourself, and assign it to the control. You can do that by assigning your data source object to the Recordset property.

When a DataTable or DataView object is assigned to the Recordset property, C1Report automatically creates an internal wrapper class that implements the interface. Because of this, you can't get the original DataTable or DataView objects back by reading the property value. Instead, you must cast the wrapper object to an and use the method instead, as shown in the example below.
remarks.value: You can assign objects of the following types to the property: (1) objects, (2) objects, or (3) any object that implements the interface.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.ExportFilter.UsesImages
member.summary: Returns a value that determines whether the filter requires page images to be generated.

remarks.para: By default, will render the report into the filter and also into its own collection.

Some filters use these images to generate their output (e.g. PDF, TIFF). Other filters don't need the images (e.g. HTML, RTF) and therefore this method returns false, which saves some resources while rendering long reports.

member.summary: Returns a value that determines whether the filter uses page images.

remarks.para: By default, C1Report will render the report into the filter and also into its own collection.
doesn't need the images and therefore this method always returns false, which saves some resources while rendering long reports.

member.returns: Always returns false.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.HtmlFilter.EncodeHtml
member.summary: Specifies whether field contents should be encoded or rendered in raw format. This property allows you to render fields that contain HTML formatting.

remarks.para: By default, field contents are encoded, so a field containing the string "A<B>C" would be rendered as "A<B>C", which would appear as the original string in the browser.
If you set to False, the same string would be rendered in raw format, causing the browser to display it as "A<B>C" (the "C" would be bold).

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.HtmlTableFilter
member.summary: Class is used with the method to render reports into table-based HTML streams or files.

remarks.para: This filter is similar to the plain , except if generates reports based on TABLE tags as opposed to absolutely-positioned DIV tags. The resulting files are usually less accurate than the ones created with the plain DIV-based , but they have three significant advantages:
1) TABLE-based reports are easier to edit in regular HTML editors. You can easily insert rows for example.
2) TABLE-based reports support clipboard operations better. For example, you can copy report sections in the browser and paste them into Excel.
3) TABLE-based reports support vertical alignment within fields.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.PdfFilter.EmbedFonts
member.summary: Specifies whether the filter should embed font information into the PDF output.

remarks.para: Embedding font information makes the PDF document substantially larger, but it allows the file to be viewed faithfully in systems that don't have all the necessary fonts installed.
Enbedding fonts is not necessary if the target systems have the necessary TrueType fonts installed.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.PdfFilter.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the owner password associated with the PDF document.

remarks.para: The owner password is required for making changes to the document.
By default, the password is set to an empty string, which means anyone can open and edit the PDF document.
The never sets the user password for the file, which means anyone can open and view the PDF document.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.PdfFilter.Outline
member.summary: Specifies whether the PDF output should include an outline tree.

remarks.para: The outline tree is created automatically based on the report groups and can be used to navigate through the report in the Adobe Acrobat viewer.
Each node in the tree corresponds to a group header section in the report. Invisible group header sections do not generate outline entries in the PDF document.
