member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.RtfLabelFilter
member.summary: Class is used with the method to render reports into RTF (rich text format) streams or files.

remarks.para: This filter is similar to the plain , except if generates RTF fields with absolute positioning. The resulting files are more accurate than the ones created with the plain RTF filter, but they are harder to edit and can only be opened in Microsoft Word (WordPad and other simple editors do not support RTF absolute positioning).

Creating an RtfLabelFilter and using it in a call to the method is similar to using the or methods, but offers some extra flexibility because you can set properties on the RtfLabelFilter before calling RenderToFilter.

After changing the value of any properties that affect the field's appearance, call this method to ensure that the report will be re-generated and the changes will be visible.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the field name.

remarks.para: The field name can be used as an index into the control's collection.
Field names are also used to identify fields in VBScript expressions, as shown in the example below.
Duplicate and empty field names are allowed, but should be avoided if you plan to use the field names in scripts or as indexers.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Visible
member.summary: Specifies whether the will be rendered in the report.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets extra data needed by the calling program.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Index
member.summary: Returns the position of the field in the parent report's collection.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Section
member.summary: Gets or sets the section to which the field belongs.
member.remarks: To move a field from one section to another, set its property to a new value.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Report
member.summary: This property is obsolete. Use the property instead.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.ParentReport
member.summary: Gets the that contains this field.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.ParentSection
member.summary: Gets the that contains this field.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's text.

remarks.para: The property contains the text that will be rendered on the report.
This value may be rendered literally (without any translation) or it may be evaluated as a VBScript expression, depending on the setting of the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Calculated
member.summary: Specifies whether the property should be interpreted as a literal value or as a calculated expression.

remarks.para: If this property is set to false, the value of the property is rendered on the report without any further processing.
If it is set to true, the value of the property is evaluated as a VBScript expression and the result of the expression is rendered on the report.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's calculated value.

remarks.para: When a field's property is set to true, the control evaluates the expression stored in the property and stores the result in the property, which gets rendered into the report.
This is the field's default property, so when you use a field name in a VBScript expression, you are actually referring to the field's property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.HideDuplicates
member.summary: Specifies whether duplicate values in consecutive records should be suppressed.

remarks.para: You can use the property to hide a field on a report when its value is the same as in the preceding record.
For example, on a report listing suppliers and their products, each supplier's name can appear once for each group of products, rather than once for each product.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.RunningSum
member.summary: Specifies whether to show a running sum for the field.

remarks.para: You can use the property to calculate record-by-record or group-by-group totals in a report.
The property specifies whether a calculated field on a report displays a running total and lets you set the range over which values are accumulated.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Left
member.summary: Gets or sets the x-coordinate of the field's left edge in twips.

remarks.para: A field's location is the distance from its upper left corner to the upper left corner of its containing .
Setting the or property to zero places the field at the very left or top of its containing section.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Top
member.summary: Gets or sets the y-coordinate of the field's top edge in twips.

remarks.para: A field's location is the distance from its upper left corner to the upper left corner of its containing .

If the field's or properties are set to true, the control will automatically adjust the property to fit the field's contents and the property of fields below the current field to preserve the vertical distance between fields. The value of the and properties is not affected.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the field in twips.

remarks.para: Every object has a rectangle, or "field box", where the field contents are rendered.
The field box is defined by the , , , and properties.
These properties are expressed in twips, and the position is relative to the field's containing section.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of the field in twips.

remarks.para: Every object has a rectangle, or "field box", where the field contents are rendered.
The field box is defined by the , , , and properties.
These properties are expressed in twips, and the position is relative to the field's containing section.
The field's property should be set to a value larger than or equal to the height of the field's , or no text will appear in the field.

If the field's or properties are set to true, the control will automatically adjust the property to fit the field's contents and the property of fields below the current field to preserve the vertical distance between fields. The value of the and properties is not affected.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.ForcePageBreak
member.summary: Specifies whether to insert page breaks before or after the field.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.CanGrow
member.summary: Specifies whether the field height should be automatically increased to fit the field's contents.

remarks.para: You can use the and properties to control the appearance of report fields and sections. When you set both properties to true, the field or section automatically adjusts so any amount of data can be printed. When a field grows or shrinks, the fields below it move down or up the page.

If you set a field's property to true, the control automatically sets the property of the containing section to true. (However, if you set a control's property to true, the control doesn't set the section's property to true.)
When you use the and properties, remember that:
1. The property settings don't affect the horizontal spacing between fields; they affect only the vertical space the fields occupy.

2. The height of a large field can prevent fields beside it from shrinking. For example, if several short controls are on the left side of a report's detail section and one tall control, such as an unbound object frame, is on the right side, the controls on the left won't shrink, even if they contain no data.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.CanShrink
member.summary: Specifies whether the field height should be automatically reduced to fit the field's contents.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.KeepTogether
member.summary: Specifies whether the field should be kept together on a page.

remarks.para: If this property is set to true, the control will insert page breaks in order to keep the field contents toghether on a page.
If it is set to false, and the containing also has its property set to false, then the field may be rendered across two or more pages.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Anchor
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's vertical position relative to its containing .

remarks.para: Normally, fields do not move when sections grow or shrink. In some cases, however, you may want fields to grow with the section or to stay in the same position relative to the bottom of the section.
This is especially common for fields used to create vertical lines that should extend the entire height of the section.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.ZOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the ZOrder for the field.

remarks.para: The ZOrder of a field determines whether it is rendered in front of or behind other fields that overlap with it.
High ZOrder values bring the field to the front, low values send it to the back.
Because ZOrder values are relative, it is usually easier to call the method, which ensures the field is rendered in front of or behind all other overlapping fields.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.RenderTop
member.summary: Gets or sets the y-coordinate of the field's top edge in twips after the and properties have been applied to the containing .
member.remarks: If the field's or properties are set to true, the control will automatically adjust the property to fit the field's contents and the property of fields below the current field to preserve the vertical distance between fields. The value of the and properties is not affected.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.RenderHeight
member.summary: Gets the height of the field in twips after the and properties have been applied to the field.
member.remarks: If the field's or properties are set to true, the control will automatically adjust the property to fit the field's contents and the property of fields below the current field to preserve the vertical distance between fields. The value of the and properties is not affected.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Bounds
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's size and location within the section, in twips.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's size, in twips.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's location within the section, in twips.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Font
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's font.
member.remarks: If you set a field's font property to a value that is too large to fit the field box (defined by the property), no text will appear in the field.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.BackColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's background color.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.ForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the field's foreground color.
member.remarks: Use the ForeColor property to specify the color for text in a field. You can use this property to make fields easy to read or to convey a special meaning.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Format
member.summary: Gets or sets a string used to format the field value.

remarks.para: You can use the property to customize the way numbers, dates, times, and text are displayed and printed.
For example, if you've created a Price field, you can set its property to "Currency". If the field value is set to "4321.678", it would be rendered as $4,321.68.
You can use the property to format numbers (including currency and percentage values), dates, boolean values, and strings.
The syntax for the format string is the same used with the .NET method.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Align
member.summary: Gets or sets how text is aligned within the field.

remarks.para: This property determines how text is aligned within the field.
To control picture alignment, use the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.WordWrap
member.summary: Specifies whether the field's contents should be allowed to wrap within the field rectangle.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.TextDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of the text within the field.
member.remarks: Not all output formats support vertical text. The preview, print, PDF, TIFF, and XLS formats do support vertical text. The HTML, RTF, and plain text formats do not.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.LineSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the line spacing between text lines in the field, in twips.
member.remarks: Setting this property to zero causes the control to use the default line spacing, which corresponds to the height of the field's font.

to define the border width (in twips).

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.LineSlant
member.summary: Specifies whether a line should be drawn across the field (as opposed to a box around the field).
member.remarks: The color, style, and thickness of the line are determined by the , , and properties.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Picture
member.summary: Gets or sets a picture to display on the field.

remarks.para: You may set this property to three types of object:
1) Regular .NET objects.
2) Strings containing image file names or urls.
3) Strings containing names of image fields in the report data source.
Options 1 and 2 are used to create unbound images, such as logos. These images do not depend on the report data.
Option 3 is used to create bound images, such as product or employee pictures. These are images stored with the report data.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.PictureAlign
member.summary: Gets or sets how field pictures should be the aligned.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.PictureScale
member.summary: Gets or sets how images should be the scaled to fit within the field area.

remarks.para: Depending on the setting of this property, images may be clipped, stretched, scaled (which preserves the image's aspect ratio), tiled, or hidden.
PictureScale works with the property so you can control image scaling and alignment independently.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.CheckBox
member.summary: Specifies whether the field should be displayed as a checkbox.
member.remarks: This property allows you to display boolean values graphically, rather than as plain text.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.RTF
member.summary: Specifies whether the field should render string enclosed in curly brackets as RTF.
member.remarks: If you set this property to true, any fields containing text enclosed in curly brackets will be rendered as RTF. This allows you to add complex formatting within a field.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.BarCode
member.summary: Allows fields to be rendered in barcode format.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.LinkTarget
member.summary: Gets or sets an expression that evaluates to a URL to be visited when the field is clicked.

remarks.para: If not empty, this should be an expression that evaluates to a URL. After the report is generated, clicking on the field will cause the report viewer to navigate to the URL. The report viewer can be a web browser (for HTML reports), Adobe Acrobat (for PDF reports), or other viewer applications.
Not all report viewers support hyperlinks. The PrintPreview control that ships with .NET, for example, does not.
The field will be displayed as usual, based on the contents of its and properties.

The expression is always evaluated, regardless of the setting of the property (which only applies to the display text). This allows you to bind the to a field in the data source, as show in the example below.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.Subreport
member.summary: Gets or sets a reference to another report to be rendered within the field (a subreport).

remarks.para: A subreport is a report that is inserted in another report. Subreports are useful when you want to combine several reports into one. For example, you may have a main report that integrates several subreports into a single main report. Or you can use the main report to show detailed information and use subreports to show summary data at the beginning of each group.
For some real-world examples, check the "Sales By Category" and "Sales By Year" reports in the NWIND.XML sample that ships with the control.
To define a field as a subreport, you should start by loading the subreport, then assign the subreport control to the field's property.

Next, link the subreport to the main report using the subreport field's property (this is analogous to setting the LinkChildFields/LinkMasterFields properties in a Microsoft Access subreport). The Text property in a subreport field is used as a filter. It specifies which records in the source recordset should be used to render the subreport based on the current record for the main report.
When the main report is being rendered and reaches the subreport field, the Text expression is evaluated and the result is uses as a filter condition for the subreport.
Building the link expression is not difficult, but it is a little tricky because it requires you to create a string that contains quotes, and these internal quotes must be doubled (written as "").

If you are creating reports using the Report Designer, you don't have to worry about building the link expressions in code. Instead, right-click the subreport field and select the Link Subreport... menu. This will show a dialog where you can select the master and detail fields. When you click OK, the Report Designer will build the link expression and assign it to the Text property of the subreport field automatically.
Subreport fields usually have the property set to true, so the subreport field can expand to include all its records.

Subreports may contain other subreports. There's no set limit for the depth of report nesting you can have. However, there must be no circular references to reports. In other words, a report cannot contain a reference to itself as a subreport.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Field.SubreportHasData
member.summary: Returns whether a subreport has data and suppresses rendering if it doesn't.
member.remarks: This property allows you to check whether a subreport has data and prevent it from rendering if it doesn't.
member.example:
The code below uses script to hide sections with empty subreports:
_c1r.Sections.Detail.OnPrint = "Detail.Visible = fSubreport.SubreportHasData"
The code below uses script to hide a field containing an empty subreport and show another field instead:
_c1r.Sections.Detail.OnPrint = "hasData = fSubreport.SubreportHasData\r\n" + "fSubreport.Visible = hasData" + "fNoData.Visible = Not hasData\r\n" +

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Group.Sort
member.summary: Gets or sets how the group is sorted.

remarks.para: Note that the sorting is performed by the data source itself, not by C1Report. Because of this, sorting is always based on column names rather than calculated expressions. If the property contains a calculated expression, the component will extract the first column name from the expression and will sort based on that value. For example, if is set to "Left(FirstName, 3)", the sorting will be based on the "FirstName" column, not on the first three characters of the first names.

This can present problems in a few cases, especially if you want ot sort based on date parts (year, month, quarter). In these cases, the recommended procedure is to add a calculated column to the data source (by changing the SQL statement used to retrieve the data), then set the property to the name of the calculated column.

remarks.para: This property determines the width of the detail section of the report.
Multi-column reports have header and footer sections that span all columns so their actual width is * .
For example, a two-column report with a one-inch wide detail section would have Width = 1440, and its total width would be 2 * 1440 = 2880.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Layout.Columns
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of detail columns.

remarks.para: Use this property to create multi-column reports.

In multi-column reports, header and footer sections span the full width of the report. Only the detail section is rendered in multiple columns. Use the property to specify the width of each column, and the property to specify whether columns should be laid out across the page or down the page.

Multi-column reports are useful for printing reports on mailing labels and other types of multi-column pre-printed forms. They are also useful for creating compact reports where detail information is laid out across the page.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Layout.OverlayReplacements
member.summary: Gets a dictionary () with replacements to be made in the report body.

remarks.para: This property is useful when implementing export filters.

Reports that contain page counts or group page counts save special tags in the report body. When the report finishes rendering, these tags need to be replaced with the actual page counts. Filters can get the list of tags and the replacement values using this dictionary. The key-value pairs in the dictionary contain the tags and their replacements.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum
member.summary: Specifies the format of the export file.
member.remarks: Use the members of this enumeration to set parameter of the method in the class.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.HTML
member.summary: Plain HTML format. This setting creates a single HTML file that can be viewed in any web browser.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.HTMLPaged
member.summary: Paged HTML format. This setting creates one HTML file for each page in the report, with links to navigate between pages.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.HTMLDrillDown
member.summary: Drill-down HTML format. This setting creates a single HTML file with collapsible headings. When viewed in a DHTML-capable browser, clicking group headers causes them to collapse and expand to show the detail.

summary.para: Adobe PDF format. This setting creates a PDF file that can be viewed using Adobe Acrobat software.
The PDF file includes an outline tree that is generated automatically based on the report structure.
Each node in the tree corresponds to a group header section in the report. Invisible group header sections do not generate outline entries in the PDF document.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.PDFEmbedFonts
member.summary: Adobe PDF format with embedded fonts. This setting creates a PDF file that can be viewed using Adobe Acrobat software.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.Text
member.summary: Plain text. This setting creates a plain ASCII file.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.RTF
member.summary: RTF format. This setting creates an RTF file that can be opened in Microsoft Word, WordPad, or any other RTF-capable text editor.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.Excel
member.summary: Microsoft Excel files. This setting creates a BIFF-8 Excel file that can be opened with Microsoft Excel 97 or later.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.TIFF
member.summary: TIFF format. This setting creates multi-page TIFF files.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.PDFPrintUtil
member.summary: Deprecated. Use PDF, PDFEmbedFonts, or PDFProcted instead.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.PDFProtected
member.summary: Protected PDF format. This setting creates a PDF file with a random password. The file can be opened and printed by anyone, but cannot be modified.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.RTFLabels
member.summary: RTF field-based format. This setting creates RTF files with absolutely-positioned fields. This format renders reports more accurately than the plain RTF format, and is recommended for creating label-style reports. However, the files created with this setting are harder to edit than the plan RTF format, and can only be previewed or printed correctly using Microsoft Word (this format doesn't work with WordPad).

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.TextSinglePage
member.summary: Plain text. This setting creates a plain ASCII file as a single page.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.Metafile
member.summary: Compressed metafile. This setting creates a zip file containing one metafile (emf) per page. The default file extensions for this format are "zip" or "emz".

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum.C1PrintDocument
member.summary: Export into a C1PrintDocument.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.GrowShrinkModeEnum
member.summary: Specifies the logic for handling CanGrow/CanShrink fields.
member.remarks: Use the members of this enumeration to set the value of the property in the class.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.GrowShrinkModeEnum.C1Report
member.summary: Uses the standard C1Report mode, where fields that grow or shrink affect only fields directly below.

member.name: F:C1.Win.C1Report.GrowShrinkModeEnum.Access
member.summary: Uses a mode that is similar to MS Access, where fields that grow or shrink affect all fields below, even if they are off to the side of the field that grew or shrank.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report
member.summary: The C1Report component generates Access-style, data-based banded reports that can be rendered directly to a printer, exported to various portable formats (including HTML, PDF, and text), or rendered into preview controls such as the Microsoft PrintPreview or ComponentOne C1PrintPreview controls.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Clear
member.summary: Clears the current report.

remarks.para: This method removes all groups, group sections, and fields from the current report.
It also resets the and objects, and clears (but does not remove) the fixed sections that all reports have: Detail, Header, Footer, PageHeader, and PageFooter.
Use this method when you want to clear a report and start creating a new one from scratch.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Evaluate(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates a VBScript expression in the current report context.
member.param: A string with a VBScript expression to be evaluated.
member.returns: The value of the expression.

remarks.para: Use this method to evaluate expressions as they would be evaluated while generating a report. This can be useful in designer-type applications, to provide an "Immediate Window" where users can test expressions.

If the expression string contains invalid syntax or causes an evaluation error, the control raises the event. In this case, the Handled parameter of the event is set to true, so the exception is ignored by default.

example.para: Expressions may contain simple VBScript expressions such as:
Expressions may also contain references to the Report object and all its sub-objects. For example:
Finally, data fields, , and objects may be referenced directly by name.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Execute(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a VBScript statement in the current report context.
member.param: A string with VBScript instructions to be executed.

remarks.para: This method is similar to the method, except it does not return a value.

If the expression string contains invalid syntax or causes an evaluation error, the control raises the event. In this case, the Handled parameter of the event is set to true, so the exception is ignored by default.

member.summary: Parses a VBScript expression in the current report context.
member.param: A string with a VBScript expression to be parsed.
member.returns: An if the expression is invalid, or null if no errors were detected.
member.remarks: This method is useful for providing VBScript syntax-checking in designer applications.

member.summary: Parses a VBScript statement in the current report context.
member.param: A string with a VBScript statement to be parsed.
member.returns: An if the statement is invalid, or null if no errors were detected.
member.remarks: This method is useful for providing VBScript syntax-checking in designer applications.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Render
member.summary: Renders the report into an internal collection of images.

remarks.para: This method is called implicitly when other classes access the property, so you rarely have to call directly from your code.
In some cases, you may want to access the report as a collection of pages, exposed by the property. To ensure that the image collection is available and up-to-date, call the method directly.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.RenderToStream(System.IO.Stream,C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum)
member.summary: Renders the report into a object.
member.param: Stream that will contain the report.
Report format to insert into the output stream.

remarks.para: This method is especially useful in ASP.NET scenarios where you want to render reports into Html or Pdf streams, without creating temporary files.
Not all types of report can be rendered into streams. The Excel format requires OLE compound files and can only be rendered into files.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.RenderToStream(System.IO.Stream,C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Renders the report into an Html .
member.param: Stream that will contain the report.
Report format to insert into the output stream.
Unique ID used to differentiate multiple reports stored in the same stream.
Base file name used to build temporary image files.
member.remarks: This method is used by the C1WebReport control to generate Html reports in ASP.NET pages.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.RenderToFile(System.String,C1.Win.C1Report.FileFormatEnum)
member.summary: Renders the report into a file.
member.param: Name of the file that will contain the report.
Type of file to create.
member.remarks: This method causes the control to render the current report into a file. It is especially useful in server applications that create several reports in batch mode, and don't have a user interface.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.RenderToFilter(C1.Win.C1Report.ExportFilter)
member.summary: Renders the report into an object.
member.param: Export filter that will render the report.

remarks.para: includes several built-in export filters that allow you to export reports to HTML, PDF, RTF, Excel, and other formats.
You may create your own filters by creating classes that derive from any of these base filters.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.CopyFrom(C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report)
member.summary: Copies a report definition from another component.
member.param: that contains the report to be copied.
member.remarks: This method is equivalent to copying the property from one to another, but is substantially faster.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.AddScriptObject(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds an object to the report's script context.
member.param: Name of the new object (case-insensitive).
Value of the new object.

remarks.para: This method allows you to add custom objects to the context of the script interpreter.
The script interpreter context is cleared whenever a report starts rendering, so this method should always be called from the event handler.

example.para: The code below uses the event to add a variable called "mainForm" to the script context. It then attaches some script to the report's event to show the caption of the form when the report starts rendering.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.AddScriptObject(System.String,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds an object to the report's script context.
member.param: Name of the new object (case-insensitive).
Value of the new object.
Whether to add the object to the script context of all subreports as well.

remarks.para: This method allows you to add custom objects to the context of the script interpreter.
The script interpreter context is cleared whenever a report starts rendering, so this method should always be called from the event handler.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.StartReport
member.summary: Fired when the control starts rendering the report, before it opens the source recordset.

remarks.para: You can use this event to provide user feedback or to make changes to the and properties.
For example, you may implement your own version of parameterized queries by asking the user to provide some information and changing the property accordingly.

You may also use this event to assign a object directly to the report's property. Applications that already have the report data should do this to save time by preventing from loading its own copy of the data.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.EndReport
member.summary: Fired when the control finishes rendering the report.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.NoData
member.summary: Fired when the control starts rendering a report and the data source is empty.

remarks.para: You can use this event to cancel rendering a report when the source recordset is empty.
If you don't cancel the report, it will be rendered as an unbound report (a self-contained report with no underlying data).

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.StartPage
member.summary: Fired when the control starts rendering each page.

remarks.para: This event is useful for updating the user interface to show how many pages have been printed so far.
You can use the property while handling this event to cancel rendering the report. To limit the number of pages that can be printed, use the property instead.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.EndPage
member.summary: Fired when the control finishes rendering each page.

remarks.para: This event is useful for updating the user interface to show how many pages have been printed so far.
You can use the property while handling this event to cancel rendering the report. To limit the number of pages that can be printed, use the property instead.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.StartSection
member.summary: Fired before each is formatted.

remarks.para: When this event fires, the report fields have not been updated with the current values or sizes.
This is a good point to set field formatting parameters and visibility based on the current data values.
This event is equivalent to the script property.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.PrintSection
member.summary: Fired before each is printed (after it has been formatted.)

remarks.para: When this event fires, the field values and sizes have been set by the control.
You may still make changes, but they will not affect the field layout. For example, changing a field's property at this point will not cause it to grow or shrink.
This event is equivalent to the script property.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.EndSection
member.summary: Fired when the control finishes rendering each .

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ReportError
member.summary: Fired when an error occurs while rendering a report.

remarks.para: The most common types of errors found when rendering reports are:

1) Invalid or parameters. This usually indicates that the system could not open the specified database (a server may be off line, or a database file may be in a different location than what was specified) or that the SQL syntax used for the property contains errors.

2) Error executing scripts or evaluating expressions. This usually indicates that the VBScript expression used contains a syntax error. In these cases, make sure you look at the exception message. It usually contains a good explanation of what caused the error.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.InitializeParametersDialog
member.summary: Fired before the control displays the Report Parameters dialog.

remarks.para: Reports that have a PARAMETERS clause in their property show a dialog where the user can enter report parameters.
This event fires before the dialog is displayed and allows you to customize the dialog by changing its caption, font, colors, etc.
You can also use this event to inspect and modify parameter values using the collection.
Finally, you can use the property to prevent the component from showing the parameters dialog.

member.name: E:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.AddOutlineEntry
member.summary: Fired before the control adds an outline entry to the report.

remarks.para: Some report output formats include an outline that is built Based on the report groups. For example, PDF reports show this outline on the left pane of the reader application.
The outline contains one entry for each group header, and the entry text is based on the value of the expression for the group.
This event allows you to change or suppress the text that appears on the outline.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ReportName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the report (used with the Load method).

remarks.para: This property identifies the report when it is saved in a report definition file.
To retrieve a report from a report definition file, use the method and pass this name as a parameter.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ReportInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets a object containing report metadata.

remarks.para: Reports may include general information such as a title, author, and keywords.

Such global information about the document itself (as opposed to its content or structure) is called metadata, and is intended to assist in cataloguing and searching for reports and report definitions in external databases.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.DataSource
member.summary: Gets a reference to the report's object.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Layout
member.summary: Gets a reference to the report's object.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Font
member.summary: Gets or sets the default font for new fields.
member.remarks: This property is not used directly when rendering the report. It is used as the default font for new fields.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.MaxPages
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of pages allowed for a report.

remarks.para: This property is useful if you want to limit the maximum number of pages in a report.
For example, you may write a report designer with a preview window that shows only the first five pages of a report.
Setting this property to zero allows reports of any length.
You can also limit the size of reports by setting the property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.DoEvents
member.summary: Specifies whether the control should handle Windows messages while rendering reports.

remarks.para: Setting this property to true allows users to resize forms, click buttons, etc. while reports are being generated. This makes applications more responsive, and is necessary if you want to provide a "Cancel Report" button (otherwise users wouldn't be able to click the button until the report was done).
Setting this property to false will cause reports to render slightly faster.

example.para: The code belows implements "Render" and a "Cancel" buttons attached to a component.

The "Render" button checks whether the component is busy before starting to render a report. This is necessary because the user could click the "Render" button several times in a row, before the component got a chance to finish rendering the report. (Calling the method while the component is busy throws an ).
The "Cancel" button checks whether the component is rendering a report and sets the property to true.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OnOpen
member.summary: Gets or sets the VBScript that is executed when the report starts rendering.

remarks.para: The control also fires the event at this time.

The difference between the regular event and the VBScript property is that the handler for the regular event belongs to the application, and should thus be used to support tasks that are independent of the report. For example, to display a message on the main window when rendering starts.

The VBScript handler in the property belongs to the report, and will be executed regardless of the application. For example, a report might contain a VBScript handler that resets global variables in the VBScript context when a report starts rendering.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OnClose
member.summary: Gets or sets the VBScript that is executed when the report finishes rendering.

remarks.para: The control also fires the event at this time.

The difference between the regular event and the VBScript property is that the handler for the regular event belongs to the application, and should thus be used to support tasks that are independent of the report. For example, to display a message on the main window when rendering finishes.

The VBScript handler in the property belongs to the report, and will be executed regardless of the application. For example, a report might contain a VBScript handler that resets global variables in the VBScript context when a report starts rendering.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OnNoData
member.summary: Gets or sets the VBScript that is executed when the report starts rendering and its source recordset is empty.

remarks.para: The control also fires the event at this time.

The difference between the regular event and the VBScript property is that the handler for the regular event belongs to the application, and should thus be used to support tasks that are independent of the report. For example, to cancel rendering reports with no data.

The VBScript handler in the property belongs to the report, and will be executed regardless of the application. For example, a report might contain a VBScript handler that changes the value of a field when the source recordset is empty.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OnPage
member.summary: Gets or sets the VBScript that is executed when a new page is created.

remarks.para: The control also fires the event at this time.

The difference between the regular event and the VBScript property is that the handler for the regular event belongs to the application, and should thus be used to support tasks that are independent of the report. For example, to update a label showing how many pages have been rendered so far.

The VBScript handler in the property belongs to the report, and will be executed regardless of the application. For example, a report might contain a VBScript handler that updates a variable at every page break.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OnError
member.summary: Gets or sets the VBScript that is executed when an error occurs.

remarks.para: The control also fires the event at this time.

The difference between the regular event and the VBScript property is that the handler for the regular event belongs to the application, and should thus be used to support tasks that are independent of the report. For example, to display a an application dialog box when an error occurs.

The VBScript handler in the property belongs to the report, and will be executed regardless of the application. For example, a report might contain a VBScript handler that changes the value of a field when an error occurs.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Page
member.summary: Gets or sets the current page number.

remarks.para: This property is a global variable available to VBScript expressions.
It is automatically initialized by the control with the value 1 when a report starts rendering, and it is automatically incremented after each page break.
This property is read-write, so you can reset it using scripts. For example, you can reset the current page to 1 whenever a new group starts rendering.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Cancel
member.summary: Specifies whether to cancel generation of the current report.
member.remarks: Setting this property to true while a report is being generated stops the report generation process. Any pages already created are kept in the document and can be previewed or printed by an attached print preview control.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.IsBusy
member.summary: Gets a value that determines whether a report is currently being generated.

remarks.para: Use this property to determine whether the control is currently busy generating a report.

This property is especially useful when the property is set to true. In this case, the application continues to process user input while the control generates reports, and there is a change that the user might try to start another report before the current one is done.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets extra data needed by the calling program.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ParentReport
member.summary: Gets the main report that contains this subreport (null for main reports).

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Document
member.summary: Gets a object that can be used to render the report to a printer or into a print preview control.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.PageImages
member.summary: Gets a list of objects that correspond to the pages in the report.
member.remarks: Use the method to create or refresh the page images.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Groups
member.summary: Gets a collection with all the groups in the report.

remarks.para: The Groups collection contains all objects defined in the current report.
Removing a Group from the collection also removes its associated header and footer sections, as well as any fields in those sections.
Adding a Group to the collection adds the corresponding group header and footer sections to the report.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Sections
member.summary: Gets the collection of objects in the report definition.
member.remarks: This collection always contains at least five items, which correspond to the standard report sections that are always present: Detail, Header, Footer, PageHeader, and PageFooter.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.Fields
member.summary: Gets the collection of objects in the report definition.
member.remarks: The object also contains a collection of fields in that section.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ReportDefinition
member.summary: Gets or sets an Xml string containing the complete report definition.
member.remarks: This property can be used to store report definitions into databases, to place them in the clipboard, or to copy reports from one component to another.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.OutlineRootLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the starting outline level for the groups in this report.

remarks.para: By default, creates an outline based on the report groups. The outline starts at level zero, and is visible in PDF versions of the report.
This property allows you to start the report at a custom level, which can be useful if you are rendering multiple reports into a larger document (using C1PrintDocument for example).
You can set this property to -1 to suppress the outline.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.LabelOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the first label on a partially used sheet.
member.remarks: This property allows you to print labels on partially used label sheets. For example, if you have a sheet with 12 labels and have already used 5, set the LabelOffset property to 6 in order to skip the labels that have already been used.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.GrowShrinkMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the method used to process CanGrow/CanShrink fields.

remarks.para: If this property is set to , fields with or properties set to true will move fields directly below them when they grow or shrink. Fields located below but off to the side are not moved.

If this property is set to , fields that grow or shrink will affect all fields below, even those which are not directly under the field that was modified as a result of CanGrow/CanShrink. (This is the Microsoft Access behavior).
For example, if fields are arranged in a grid layout and is set to , fields within each row will remain vertically aligned when fields above them grow or shrink.
If is set to , fields within each column will move independently of fields in other columns, and fields within each row will not remain vertically aligned.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.UsePrinterResolution
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should use the .NET printing support to obtain high-resolution graphics.

remarks.para: By default, scans the installed printers in order to obtain a high-resolution reference object.

Set this property to false in order to bypass this process and use the screen resolution when generating reports. This will increase report rendering speed (in some cases) with some loss in layout accuracy.

Under certain circumstances, notably when running under Windows Services, the .NET printing support does not work correctly, and trying to enumerate the installed printers may cause memory allocation problems. In these situations, setting this property to false is necessary.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.IgnoreScriptErrors
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should ignore script errors by default.

remarks.para: When the script interpreter finds an error in a script or expression, the component raises the event. This property specifies the default value for the Handled parameter in that event.
If IgnoreScriptErrors is set to true, script errors are ignored by default (the Handled parameter is initialized to true).
If IgnoreScriptErrors is set to false, script errors throw exceptions by default (the Handled parameter is initialized to false).
In either case, the event handler may override the default by changing the value of the Handled parameter.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.ExposeScriptObjects
member.summary: Specifies whether script objects added with the method should be exposed to subreports.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report.EditExpressionDelegate
member.summary: Type of delegate used to specify custom handlers for script editors.

remarks.para: When component is used with a control, the property grid uses custom type editors to provide user interface elements for editing scripts, statements, and data source properties.
This delegate allows report designer applications to provide their own user interface for editing these elements.
For examples of how these delegates are used, please see the source code for the C1ReportDesigner application, included with the C1Report Designer Edition.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.ReportScript
member.summary: ReportScript extends the ScriptEngine class to recognizing the following custom objects: - database fields - report fields - custom variables: Page - custom functions: Sum, etc

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.Util.ScriptEngine.ScriptEngine
member.summary:
-------------------------------------------------------------------- ScriptEngine -------------------------------------------------------------------- ScriptEngine parses strings and returns Expression or Statement objects that can be evaluated/executed.
The base class provides only simple expression evaluation. For most practical applications, you will need to add variables and custom objects to the engine, so scripts can assign values etc.
To do this, you should derive a new class from ScriptEngine and override the following member:
public virtual object GetObjectByName(string strName)
This function should return an object. The object can be a simple value type (e.g. "pi" returns 3.14), or an object with properties and methods (e.g. myobj.Left). To allow getting and setting the default property, the object must implement a property called "Value" (e.g. myobj = 12 is the same as myobj.Value = 12).
This class has two main members:
- ParseExpression(str) returns an Expression object that can be evaluated very quickly. This returns a value (object type). - ParseStatement(str) returns a Statement object that can be executed. This does not return anything.
It also has two useful helpers:
- Evaluate(str) parses the expression in str and evaluates it. - Execute(str) parses the statement in str and executes it.
These helpers are convenient, but calling them repeatedly is slower than using the ParseExpression/ParseStatement and evaluating/executing the results (because the latter only parses once).

member.summary: ScriptValueWrapper is a helper class that wraps simple objects and exposes a Value property so the ScriptEngine can assign them new values.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.Section
member.summary: Represents a report band.

remarks.para: Each Section object contains a collection of fields objects that display individual data items within the section.
Every report contains the following sections:
A detail section.
A report header and a report footer section.
A page header and a page footer section.
A group header and a group footer section for each object in the report.
The total number of sections in a report is therefore 5 + 2 * Groups.Count. Sections cannot be added and removed from reports directly. The number of sections is a function of the number of groups.
Although sections cannot be removed, they can be hidden by setting their property to false.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name.

remarks.para: The section name can be used as an index into the control's collection.
Section names are also used to identify fields in VBScript expressions.
Duplicate and empty section names are allowed, but should be avoided if you plan to use the section names in scripts or as indexers.

member.summary: Gets or sets the height, in twips.

remarks.para: The height of a section should be large enough to accommodate all fields in the section.
The Report Designer automatically adjusts section heights when fields are added, moved, or resized.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.RenderHeight
member.summary: Returns the height of the section after the and properties have been applied to the section.

remarks.para: When a section grows or shrinks, its property does not change.
If you need to retrieve the actual height that will be used for rendering the section (for example, while handling the event), use the property instead.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.KeepTogether
member.summary: Specifies whether the should be kept together on a page.

remarks.para: The and objects also have KeepTogether properties.
The object's property works across sections. It determines whether group headers should be kept together with their first detail section or whether entire groups should be kept together on a page.
The object's property determines whether the field should be rendered on a single page or whether it is allowed to be split across page breaks.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.ForcePageBreak
member.summary: Specifies whether page breaks should be inserted before and/or after the section is rendered.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.CanGrow
member.summary: Specifies whether the Section height should be automatically increased to fit its contents.

remarks.para: You can use the and properties to control the appearance of report sections and fields.
For example, if you set both properties to true, a section or field automatically adjusts vertically to print or preview all the data it contains.
Sections grow and shrink vertically across their entire width.
When a section grows or shrinks, its property does not change. To retrieve the actual rendering height, use the property.
You can make fields grow or shrink to match the size of the section by setting their property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.CanShrink
member.summary: Specifies whether the height should be reduced when one or more fields shrink.

remarks.para: You can use the and properties to control the layout of report sections and fields.
For example, if you set both properties to true, a section or field automatically adjusts vertically to print or preview all the data it contains.
When a section grows or shrinks, its property does not change. To retrieve the actual (adjusted) height, use the property.
You can make fields grow or shrink to match the size of the section by setting their property.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.Repeat
member.summary: Specifies whether the should be repeated at the top of every page.

remarks.para: This property only applies to group header sections.
Set this value to true to repeat the group header page at the top of every page, before the detail sections.
If you have multiple groups, all group header sections that have the Repeat property set to true will be rendered at the top of each page.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.BackColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color for this .

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.OnFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets a string containing VBScript code to be executed before the is formatted.

remarks.para: This property contains VBScript instructions to be executed before the fields in the section are calculated. When this script is executed, the recordset already holds the data that will be displayed in the section, but the field values have not been updated yet.

Use this event to assign values to fields before they are calculated, so the new values will be taken into account when the control calculates the field's size and position when the or properties are set to true.
If you want to set field properties based on the field's current value, use the property instead.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.Section.OnPrint
member.summary: Gets or sets a string containing VBScript code to be executed before the is printed (after it is formatted).
member.remarks: This property contains VBScript instructions that get executed after the fields in the section have been calculated.

member.name: T:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter
member.summary: Class used with the method to render reports into Microsoft Excel (XLS) files.
member.remarks: Creating an XlsFilter and using it in a call to the method is similar to using the method, but offers some extra flexibility because you can set properties on the XlsFilter before calling RenderToFilter.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class attached to a file.
member.param: Full name of the file to be created.
member.remarks: If the file already exists, the filter will open it and will add a new sheet with the report.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.StartReport(C1.Win.C1Report.C1Report)
member.summary: Called when the component starts rendering a report.
member.param: Owner report.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.IsPaged
member.summary: Determines whether this filter generates single or multi-page reports.
member.returns: Always returns false.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.UsesImages
member.summary: Returns a value that determines whether the filter uses page images.
member.returns: Always returns false.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.RenderField(C1.Win.C1Report.Field,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.String,System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Called when the component needs to render a report field with specific content at a specific position on the current page.
member.param: object to render.
Rectangle that determines the field position on the page, in twips.
Field text to render.
Field image to render.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.EndReport
member.summary: Called when the component finishes rendering a report.

member.name: M:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.Dispose
member.summary: Called when the component finishes rendering a report, or when the rendering process is canceled by the user or interrupted by an error.
member.remarks: Use this method to free any disposable objects used by the filter.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.SheetName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the worksheet to be used when saving the report into the Excel workbook file.
member.remarks: You can use this property to save multiple reports into a single Excel workbook file, one on each sheet.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.Shading
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether cells should be shaded in the Excel workbook file.
member.remarks: Set this property to false to create smaller files without any cell shading.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.Images
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether images should be exported to the Excel workbook file.
member.remarks: Set this property to false to create smaller files without any images.

member.name: P:C1.Win.C1Report.XlsFilter.FreezePageHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether header sections should be frozen on the sheet.
member.remarks: Set this property to true to freeze rows that contain the ReportHeader and PageHeader sections. Frozen rows remain visible when the user scrolls the sheet.
